review:
A Mysterious Puzzle World Unveiled: Review of "Doodle Mafia"

Rating: â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜†â˜† (3/5)

"Doodle Mafia" invites players to step into the shoes of a crime lord, shaping the underworld through the fusion of various criminal elements and activities. Developed by JoyBits Ltd., this puzzle game offers a unique twist on the "Doodle" series by delving into the world of organized crime. While providing an intriguing premise and puzzle-solving challenges, the game might not fully capture the engaging magic of its predecessors.

The gameplay of "Doodle Mafia" revolves around combining elements to create new ones, just like its predecessors "Doodle God" and "Doodle God Blitz." However, this time, the focus is on crafting a criminal empire. Players experiment with mixing different elements representing crime, law enforcement, and other societal components to create a range of criminal activities, from petty theft to full-blown syndicates.

The narrative framework is minimal, allowing players to focus on the puzzle-solving aspects. As you unlock new combinations, you piece together your criminal empire's progression and unravel new story elements.

The visual style maintains the doodle aesthetic of the series, and while it doesn't deviate from the established formula, it still carries its own charm. The simple graphics contribute to the game's casual atmosphere, making it accessible to a wide range of players.

One of the highlights of "Doodle Mafia" is the array of combinations available. Experimenting and discovering new ways to create criminal activities, law enforcement measures, and societal aspects adds an element of discovery and creativity to the experience.

However, "Doodle Mafia" also faces certain limitations. While the criminal theme is unique and intriguing, it might not resonate with all players. The game's simplified approach to gameplay might also feel repetitive after a while, especially for those who've experienced the more complex mechanics of the earlier "Doodle" games.

The lack of complexity in the puzzles might lead to less engagement for players seeking a more cerebral challenge. Additionally, the absence of a deeper narrative or an overarching goal might make the gameplay feel somewhat aimless for some players.

In conclusion, "Doodle Mafia" offers a fresh twist on the elemental combination puzzle genre, letting players craft a criminal underworld from scratch. The puzzle-solving challenges and the joy of discovery are definite strengths, providing players with a creative outlet to experiment with different combinations. However, the game's simplicity and lack of a more intricate narrative might limit its long-term appeal, especially for fans of the more complex and immersive experiences found in the earlier "Doodle" titles. If you're intrigued by the idea of exploring a criminal empire through puzzle-solving, "Doodle Mafia" might be the intriguing diversion you're looking for.

review:
[b][u]Game Information[/u][/b]

"Doodle Mafia"  is a Puzzle game. The game was developed and published by JoyBits.

[b][u]The Game Review[/u][/b]

Game Visuals

I want to mention that the visuals for the game are well done. The visuals can be adjusted in the game's menu option.

Game Audio

I want to mention that audio for the game is well done. Even though the audio is somewhat simplistic and repetitive. The audio can be adjusted in the game's option menu as well.

Gameplay

There are no difficulty game modes. Each of the puzzles has their own difficulty.

The objective is to combine two existing elements to create a new element. There are numerous possible combinations that would work and would not work.

There are fourteen different achievements that can be unlocked from playing the game. Each of these achievements does come with some requirements that need to be completed before they can be unlocked.

Miscellaneous

There are six different trading cards to collect. Only three of those trading cards are given out by the game. There are several ways to get the rest of the trading cards: Purchased from the Steam's Community Market; Trade with friends; Booster Packs and its Booster Pack Creator.

Final thoughts: I have found the game enjoyable to a certain extent. The replay value for this game is low. I would recommend this game but not at the game's full price value.

review:
Doodle Mafia is a mobile app that's been dumped on Steam as a lazy, greedy cash grab.  It's a ripoff of the Element game from iOS from last decade.   The only key difference is they switched the elements you match with "crime" related elements, which makes even less sense than the original Elements game did.   "Metal bar + Murder = Weapon??".    From this we can deduct the only crime here is the drugs the mobile devs were on when they thought this was a good idea. 

It's quite remarkable these guys have been peddling a ripoff of Elements for so long.  Either way, it's still derivative and not notably better than the original mobile game.  And of course, mobile games don't belong on Steam, so I can't recommend this.

review:
[i]Doodle Mafia[/i] is possibly my thematically favourite of the [i]Doodle[/i] franchise. 
But, in a similar fashion as its predecessors or successors, the elements combining can get unnecessarily convoluted to the point of frustration. This problem isn't showing up in the early stages of the game, and you can try and combine everything to the fullest potential. In the late game, on the other hand, it usually is about combining two specific elements. This process (without using hints) can be a massive head-scratcher, that goes against common sense and intuition. I genuinely felt anger on few occasions.

The [i]campaign[/i] mode is ok. It provides something bit different. Combining elements feels more purposeful and it makes you think just a tiny bit. There is also a [i]slot machine[/i] of sorts, and I have no clue what it does, neither I have the desire to play it(?). 

The thing that is worth mentioning as well is somewhat frustrating menu interface, especially in campaign mode trying to get out of there to the main screen. It is quite clunky.

[i]Doodle Mafia[/i] offers simple casual mobile game experience if your preference is mouse instead of a touchscreen. The game doesn't offer anything else besides the elements combining, so if you feel this could be your thing, I would recommend it ... but probably more so, when the game will be on sale.

OK experience for few hours, when you simply want to kill some time, which I'm trying to do a lot in my daily life.

[i]Grade:[/i][b] C[/b]

review:
âœ˜ What is the purpose of a game?

To entertain, inform, and/or please the player. 

I found this game provided [i]none[/i] of that. I love simulation games, especially ones that have a repeating pattern (blame growing up playing free flash games!) and when I saw this in an Fanatical bundle, I was pleased by the description, and lured in by the promise of an engaging story. 

I didn't get any of that.

The 'story' can be seen in campaign mode, a short, frustrating series of chapters that provide little besides boredom. Essentially the game is about chemistry - adding things together (like nixon + p rostitu te suzy = dirty secret) that create an 'element'. In campaign mode, your reward for creating elements is progression in the 'story' (aka a line or two of 'storyline' text), in city mode the background scene develops, giving you cash to spend in the (afterthought?) gamble mode. 

You could say the game gave me reptition. Yes. It did. It boils down to creating elements, for a total of 288 combinations, and 5-6 campaign modes. Though, it should give you an award for amount of mouse clicks - the controls are lousy, relying mainly on clicking, clicking, clicking. Once you have over a hundred elements or so, sorting through them can be confusing, and instead of being able to search/type for them, you'll need to look in the dictionary-like pages, click the one you need, then do so on the other page. Tedious, to say the least. 

Just like the rest of the game. -:(

author: {'steamid': '76561198018483984', 'num_games_owned': 1970, 'num_reviews': 132, 'playtime_forever': 126, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 126, 'last_played': 1516293485}
review:
[b]Note: I received a gift copy through the Steam Curator System. I have decided not to feature it on my curator page, but am still writing a review.[/b]

In Doodle Mafia we're given five starting elements, crime, person, metal bar, wallet and building. You then combine these elements with simple clicking to create a new one. For example, crime + metal bar = break in, wallet + crime = theft and so on. You now have a 5th element which you can use to combine and this goes on until you've managed to find the combinations for 288 different things. As you uncover each element, it changes something visually on the map. It does have a basic element of strategy, but you can easily brute force it by simple trial and error. 

There's an open world where you work on unlocking everything for your city, a campaign which gives you a different story premise and you must unlock the right things to complete the story, and there's a mini casino slots game where you can use dollars you earn in the city and campaign to spin and uh.. make more dollars? I don't see the point of this, as there doesn't seem to be anything else you can do with it.

If you've played Doodle God, you'll find this game very similar. If anything, although the store description claims it's the biggest Doodle game to date, it seems to have slightly less elements, less puzzles and also no competitive edge with Doodle God's leaderboards and tournaments. That being said, it's also half the price and definitely still has many, many hours of addictive clickery so I'm not complaining about content. 

Just like my recommendation for Doodle God, you're going to enjoy this if you like very casual clicking and time wasting. It has a unique theme that some people may prefer and I think that spices it up a little but crime isn't really my thing, so I think on the whole I preferred the original. 

As with all the Doodle Games, it's available on the iOS and Google Play store far cheaper than steam, is enjoyable in short bursts, and really works well as a time waster on the go. It's also better suited in my opinion to touch screen mechanics than clicking, and I'd recommend the original "Doodle God" if you haven't played any at all, for it's extra puzzles and competitive elements, unless you really like the theme of crime sprees.

[h1]I'd recommend this for a casual time wasting puzzle-lite game with a mafia / crime theme, but it may be more fun for you on mobile formats.[/h1]

review:
Another Doodle game, I have to admit, there is something oddly calming in solving these puzzles for me. Can't say the same for the Casino minigame, which had its use on the IOS but here on Steam it's quite pointless. 

But other than that, the main game mode is as fun as always, this time with added visual representation of how your actions  affect the city(ok, so it's just a simple drawing which slowly changes with your progress. Nothing crazy, but still appreciated)

The side stories, where you follow a cop and a criminal are a nice addition, but they're still rather short and end quite abruptly. 

All in all-if you like Doodle games and you're not tired with this formula, then you should definitively buy it...though it say it's more of a 3 euro game rather than 6. so wait for a better offer ;)

review:
Was recommended this game by steam, so yeah thought I would give it a go. This is where the problems started happening! 
I have Norton Anti Virus on my Laptop and it flagged it as suspicious, Norton Power Eraser also flagged it as "Dangerous". So I tried it on another PC that uses AVG. Again this also flagged as suspicious.

Booted the game up on a slave PC which has nothing special on it and disabled the Anti Virus.

The game it's self is okay. Graphics are okay. Although some of the steam acheivements are hard to get.

Now onto the customer service from the developer!
When several people report your game is showing false positives you would have thought that a decent developer that cares about its players would jump to sort out the issue. No instead they blame the player and then tell the player to contact the likes of Norton and AVG!!!  Even when the player does that the developer makes no acknowledgement of the players actions!

Great game, poor customer service and false positives on Anti Virus that the developer doesn't care about.

Edit: Since I posted this review the devloper has now sent personal attacks at me for writing the truth. This further shows how much the devloper cares for its players!!!
